Quoting Johannes Link <john.link@...>:

> > >- It's implementation-based (white-box) because you must be aware
> of
> > the
> > >implementation to decide when a sufficient coverage level has been
> > reached.
> > 
> > I don't understand the second point. (Pause.) Wait, maybe I do. I
> use
> > my knowledge of the current implementation that passes the current
> > tests to decide what test to write next, if any. Is that what you
> mean?
> 
> Right. Imagine the simple case that the test passes although a certain
> getter returns a constant string. It's obvious then that something in
> the code is
> not perfect yet - a strong indicator for a missing test.

True, but this is more an issue of knowing whether the implementation is "fake" 
or not. That's a special case. In the case of two competing implementations 
that both *at least try* to meet the requirements, it's best to have tests that 
can't tell the difference between the two.

> My point: The term "black-box" or "specification-based" has two aspects:
> 
> (1) usage: only use the public interface of the component under test)
> (2) knowledge: only use the specification of external behaviour to
> derive
> test cases
> Whereas (1) is at least a goal to strive for, (2) is IMO not valid for
> "unit
> tests" as used in test-first development.

Again, I'm not sure I agree with your second point. (Could there be a pattern 
here? :) In TDD, test cases are not derived from an implementation; instead, 
they drive the implementation. (Hence Test-Driven Development.) The best tests 
are ones that:

* Test everything that could possibly break in the current implementation
* Are sufficiently implementation-independent to support easier refactoring
* Run quickly, are small, easy to read...

I realize that these are competing forces, so the challenge is striking the 
right balance. I find my life difficult when my tests get in the way of my 
refactorings... tests that have intimate knowledge of the implementation tend 
to be refactoring-resistant. I tend away from them if I can.
